Name: Abacus
Note: A standard tool used to make calculations.

Name: Acid (vial)
Note: As an action, you can splash the contents of this vial onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw the vial up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the acid as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 acid damage.

Name: Alchemist's Fire (flask)
Note: This sticky, adhesive fluid ignites when exposed to air. As an action, you can throw this flask up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the alchemist's fire as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 1d4 fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature can end this damage by using its action to make a DC 10 Dexterity check to extinguish the flames.

Name: Alms Box
Note: A small box for alms, typically found in a priest's pack.

Name: Antitoxin
Note: A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs.

Name: Backpack
Note: A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear. You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

Name: Ball Bearings (bag of 1,000)
Note: As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level, square area that is 10 feet on a side. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the save.

Name: Barding
Note: Barding is armor designed to protect an animal’s head, neck, chest, and body. Any type of armor can be purchased as barding. The cost is four times the equivalent armor made for humanoids, and it weighs twice as much.

Name: Barrel
Note: A barrel can hold 40 gallons of liquid, or 4 cubic feet of solid material.

Name: Basket
Note: A basket can hold 2 cubic feet/40 pounds of gear.

Name: Bedroll
Note: You never know where you’re going to sleep, and a bedroll helps you get better sleep in a hayloft or on the cold ground. A bedroll consists of bedding and a blanket thin enough to be rolled up and tied. In an emergency, it can double as a stretcher.

Name: Bell
Note: A standard bell that rings, typically used for signaling.

Name: Bit and Bridle
Note: Standard equipment used to direct a mount.

Name: Blanket
Note: A thick, quilted, blanket made to keep you warm in cold weather.

Name: Block and Tackle
Note: A set of pulleys with a cable threaded through them and a hook to attach to objects, a block and tackle allows you to hoist up to four times the weight you can normally lift.

Name: Block of Incense
Note: A block of incense, typically found in a priest's pack.

Name: Bomb
Note: As an action, a character can light this bomb and throw it at a point up to 60 feet away. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw or take 3d6 fire damage.

Name: Book
Note: A book might contain poetry, historical accounts, information pertaining to a particular field of lore, diagrams and notes on gnomish contraptions, or just about anything else that can be represented using text or pictures. A book of spells is a spellbook.

Name: Bottle, Glass
Note: A bottle can hold 1 1/2 pints of liquid.

Name: Bucket
Note: A bucket can hold 3 gallons of liquid, or 1/2 cubic foot of solid material.

Name: Caltrops (bag of 20)
Note: As an action, you can spread a bag of caltrops to cover a square area that is 5 feet on a side. Any creature that enters the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or stop moving this turn and take 1 piercing damage. Taking this damage reduces the creature's walking speed by 10 feet until the creature regains at least 1 hit point. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the save.

Name: Candle
Note: For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

Name: Canoe
Note: A canoe can be purchased in Port Nyanzaru for 50 gp. It holds up to six Medium creatures and has a maximum speed of 2 mph. It is otherwise identical to a rowboat.

Name: Carpenter's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Cartographer's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Case, Crossbow Bolt
Note: This wooden case can hold up to twenty crossbow bolts.

Name: Case, Map or Scroll
Note: This cylindrical leather case can hold up to ten rolled-up sheets of paper or five rolled-up sheets of parchment.

Name: Censer
Note: A censer, typically found in a priest's pack.

Name: Chain (10 feet)
Note: A chain has 10 hit points. It can be burst with a successful DC 20 Strength check.

Name: Chalk
Note: A piece of chalk used for writing and marking on various surfaces.

Name: Chest
Note: A chest can hold 12 cubic feet/ 300 pounds of gear.

Name: Climber's Kit
Note: A climber's kit includes special pitons, boot tips, gloves, and a harness. You can use the climber's kit as an action to anchor yourself; when you do, you can't fall more than 25 feet from the point where you anchored yourself, and you can't climb more than 25 feet away from that point without undoing the anchor.

Name: Clothes, Common
Note: This set of clothes could consist of a loose shirt and baggy breeches, or a loose shirt and skirt or overdress. Cloth wrappings are used for shoes.

Name: Clothes, Costume
Note: This set of clothes is fashioned after a particular costume, typically meant for entertaining.

Name: Clothes, Fine
Note: This set of clothes is designed specifically to be expensive and to show it, including fancy, tailored clothes in whatever fashion happens to be the current style in the courts of the nobles.Precious metals and gems could be worked into the clothing.

Name: Clothes, Traveler's
Note: This set of clothes could consist of boots, a wool skirt or breeches, a sturdy belt, a shirt (perhaps with a vest or jacket), and an ample cloak with a hood.

Name: Cobbler's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Component Pouch
Note: A component pouch is a small, watertight leather belt pouch that has compartments to hold all the material components and other special items you need to cast your spells, except for those components that have a specific cost (as indicated in a spell's description).

Name: Crowbar
Note: Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

Name: Disguise Kit
Note: This pouch of cosmetics, hair dye, and small props lets you create disguises that change your physical appearance. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any Ability Checks you make to create a visual disguise.

Name: Feed (per day)
Note: Standard feed typically consumed by a mount per day.

Name: Fishing Tackle
Note: This kit includes a wooden rod, silken line, corkwood bobbers, steel hooks, lead sinkers, velvet lures, and narrow netting.

Name: Flask or Tankard
Note: A flask or tankard can hold 1 pint of liquid.

Name: Forgery Kit
Note: This small box contains a variety of papers and parchments, pens and inks, seals and Sealing wax, gold and silver leaf, and other supplies necessary to create convincing forgeries of physical documents. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any Ability Checks you make to create a physical forgery of a document.

Name: Glassblower's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Grappling Hook
Note: When tied to the end of a rope, a grappling hook can secure the rope to a battlement, window ledge, tree limb, or other protrusion.

Name: Gunpowder, Keg
Note: Setting fire to a container full of gunpowder can cause it to explode, dealing fire damage to creatures within 10 feet of it (7d6). A successful DC 12 Dexterity saving throw halves the damage. Setting fire to an ounce of gunpowder causes it to flare for 1 round, shedding bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

Name: Gunpowder, Powder Horn
Note: Setting fire to a container full of gunpowder can cause it to explode, dealing fire damage to creatures within 10 feet of it (3d6). A successful DC 12 Dexterity saving throw halves the damage. Setting fire to an ounce of gunpowder causes it to flare for 1 round, shedding bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet.

Name: Hammer
Note: This one-handed hammer with an iron head is useful for pounding pitons into a wall.

Name: Hammer, Sledge
Note: This two-handed, iron-headed hammer is good for smashing open treasure chests.

Name: Healer's Kit
Note: This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The kit has ten uses. As an action, you can expend one use of the kit to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points, without needing to make a Wisdom (Medicine) check.

Name: Herbalism Kit
Note: This kit contains a variety of instruments such as clippers, mortar and pestle, and pouches and vials used by herbalists to create remedies and potions. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any Ability Checks you make to Identify or apply herbs. Also, proficiency with this kit is required to create Antitoxin and potions of Healing.

Name: Holy Water (flask)
Note: As an action, you can splash the contents of this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a target creature, treating the holy water as an improvised weapon. If the target is a fiend or undead, it takes 2d6 radiant damage.

Name: Hourglass
Note: A standard hourglass used to measure the passage of time.

Name: Hunting Trap
Note: When you use your action to set it, this trap forms a saw-toothed steel ring that snaps shut when a creature steps on a pressure plate in the center. The trap is affixed by a heavy chain to an immobile object, such as a tree or a spike driven into the ground. A creature that steps on the plate must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d4 piercing damage and stop moving. Thereafter, until the creature breaks free of the trap, its movement is limited by the length of the chain (typically 3 feet long). A creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Each failed check deals 1 piercing damage to the trapped creature.

Name: Ink (1 ounce bottle)
Note: Ink is typically used with an ink pen to write.

Name: Ink Pen
Note: An ink pen is a wooden stick with a special tip on the end. The tip draws ink in when dipped in a vial and leaves an ink trail when drawn across a surface.

Name: Insect Repellant-Salve
Note: One application protects its wearer against normal insects for 24 hours. The salve is waterproof so it doesn’t wash off in rain.

Name: Insect Repellent-Incense
Note: When lit, it burns for 8 hours and repels normal insects within a 20-foot-radius centered on it.

Name: Jeweler's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Jug or Pitcher
Note: A jug or pitcher can hold 1 gallon of liquid.

Name: Ladder (10 foot)
Note: This item is a straight, simple wooden ladder.

Name: Lamp
Note: A lamp casts bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

Name: Lantern, Bullseye
Note: A bullseye lantern casts bright light in a 60-foot cone and dim light for an additional 60 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

Name: Lantern, Hooded
Note: A hooded lantern casts bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil. As an action, you can lower the hood, reducing the light to dim light in a 5-foot radius.

Name: Leatherworker's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Little Bag of Sand
Note: A small bag of sand, typically found in a scholar's pack.

Name: Lock
Note: A key is provided with the lock. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick this lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Your DM may decide that better locks are available for higher prices.

Name: Magnifying Glass
Note: This lens allows a closer look at small objects. It is also useful as a substitute for flint and steel when starting fires. Lighting a fire with a magnifying glass requires light as bright as sunlight to focus, tinder to ignite, and about 5 minutes for the fire to ignite. A magnifying glass grants advantage on any ability check made to appraise or inspect an item that is small or highly detailed.

Name: Manacles
Note: These metal restraints can bind a Small or Medium creature. Escaping the manacles requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. Breaking them requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. Each set of manacles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick the manacles' lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Manacles have 15 hit points.

Name: Mason's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Mess Kit
Note: This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

Name: Mirror, Steel
Note: A steel mirror is handy when you want to look around corners, signal friends with reflected sunlight, keep an eye on a medusa, make sure that you look good enough to present yourself to the queen, or examine wounds that you’ve received on hard-to-see parts of your body.

Name: Navigator's Tools
Note: This set of instruments is used for navigation at sea. Proficiency with Navigator's Tools lets you chart a ship's course and follow navigation charts. In addition, these tools allow you to add your proficiency bonus to any ability check you make to avoid getting lost at sea.

Name: Oil (flask)
Note: Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

Name: Paper (one sheet)
Note: A sheet of standard paper is made from cloth fibers.

Name: Parchment (one sheet)
Note: A sheet of parchment is a piece of goat hide or sheepskin that has been prepared for writing on.

Name: Perfume (vial)
Note: A fragrant commodity typically used by the wealthy.

Name: Pick, Miner's
Note: A miner's pick is designed to concentrate the force of its blow on a small area.

Name: Piton
Note: When a wall doesn’t offer handholds and footholds, you can make your own. A piton is a steel spike with an eye through which you can loop a rope.

Name: Poisoner’s Kit
Note: A poisoner’s kit includes the vials, chemicals, and other Equipment necessary for the Creation of Poisons. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any Ability Checks you make to craft or use Poisons.

Name: Pole (10-foot)
Note: When you suspect a trap, you can put the end of your 10-foot pole through that hole in the wall instead of reaching in with your hand.

Name: Pot, Iron
Note: An iron pot can hold 1 gallon of liquid.

Name: Potter's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Pouch
Note: A cloth or leather pouch can hold 1/5 cubic foot/ 6 pounds of gear - or up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch.

Name: Quiver
Note: A quiver can hold up to 20 arrows.

Name: Ram, Portable
Note: You can use a portable ram to break down doors. When doing so, you gain a +4 bonus on the Strength check. One other character can help you use the ram, giving you advantage on this check.

Name: Rations (1 day)
Note: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

Name: Robes
Note: A standard set of robes.

Name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
Note: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Rope, Silk (50 feet)
Note: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Sack
Note: A sack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

Name: Saddle, Exotic
Note: An exotic saddle is required for riding any aquatic or flying mount.

Name: Saddle, Military
Note: A military saddle braces the rider, helping you keep your seat on an active mount in battle. It gives you advantage on any check you make to remain mounted.

Name: Saddle, Pack
Note: A standard saddle for a pack mount.

Name: Saddle, Riding
Note: A standard saddle for a riding mount.

Name: Saddlebags
Note: Standard saddlebags that can be attached to a mount's saddle.

Name: Scale, Merchant's
Note: A scale includes a small balance, pans, and a suitable assortment of weights up to 2 pounds. With it, you can measure the exact weight of small objects, such as raw precious metals or trade goods, to help determine their worth.

Name: Sealing Wax
Note: When you press a signet ring into warm sealing wax, you leave an identifying mark.

Name: Shovel
Note: A standard shovel used for digging.

Name: Signal Whistle
Note: A small whistle used for signaling.

Name: Signet Ring
Note: Each signet ring has a distinctive design carved into it. When you press this ring into warm sealing wax, you leave an identifying mark.

Name: Small Knife
Note: A small knife, typically found in a scholar's pack.

Name: Smith's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Soap
Note: A commodity used for bathing.

Name: Spellbook
Note: Essential for wizards, a spellbook is a leather-bound tome with 100 blank vellum pages suitable for recording spells.

Name: Spikes, Iron (10)
Note: Standard iron spikes typically used with a hammer.

Name: Spyglass
Note: Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size.

Name: Stake (Wooden)
Note: Stakes made out of wood, typically found in a monster hunter's pack.

Name: String
Note: A 10-foot length of string, typically found in a burglar's pack.

Name: Tent, Two-Person
Note: A simple and portable canvas shelter, a tent sleeps two.

Name: Thieves' Tools
Note: This set of tools includes a small file, a set of lock picks, a small mirror mounted on a metal handle, a set of narrow-bladed scissors, and a pair of pliers. Proficiency with these tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any Ability Checks you make to disarm traps or open locks.

Name: Tinderbox
Note: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

Name: Tinker's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Torch
Note: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

Name: Vestments
Note: Religious clothing, typically found in a priest's pack.

Name: Vial
Note: A vial can hold 4 ounces of liquid.

Name: Waterskin
Note: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

Name: Weaver's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.

Name: Whetstone
Note: A standard whetstone used to sharpen blades.

Name: Woodcarver's Tools
Note: These Special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade.
